Description:

Title: John's Southport Soup Kitchen 10k Challenge

Description:
The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (UCKG) is a Christian Ministry and registered charity (1043985) dedicated to helping people live life to the fullest — physically, emotionally and spiritually.

Over the years, we have reached such a diverse group of people that our work has touched millions across over 170 countries. Their unique stories remind us that with the right kind of help and support, the most heartbreaking stories can become tomorrow’s inspirational ones. In these testing times, we are determined to do more. Support us
Title: Sandie's Fundraising for Soup Kitchen and support of the homeless.

Description:
This year I'am raising funds to help the work of the Soup Kitchen in the community of Catford. The soup Kitchen is open every Saturday from 11:00 am to 13:00 pm. it's a place where those who are in need can have a hot meal and also get groceries to take home. 

This year the numbers of people helped through the Soup Kitchen has triples due the current pandemic.

Your donation will make a huge difference in supporting the Soup Kitchen during this festive season.

Title: 5Alive! Soup Kitchen

Description:
The UCKG HelpCentre is a UK charity dedicated to helping people live life to the full. Over the years, we’ve reached such a large and diverse group of individuals that our growing family now includes some 12 million people from all walks of life, across 172 countries.

5 Alive comprises of 5 different areas we want your help in order to help others through:
1. Night Angels: giving food to the homeless at night.

2. Give Warmth Appeal: giving warmth to the homeless and less fortunate

3. Soup Kitchen: every Saturday from 11am-1pm we are feeding over 30,000 of the hungry in our community yearly

4. 24/7 Helpline: volunteering advisors are available to speak with and give support to those who are desperate and need support

5. Food Bank: helping more than 7,000 families per year within our community

With your sponsorship, we plan to open 15 more Food Banks which will enable us to more than double the amount of people we will reach each year.

Description: Soup Kitchen is run by our amazing Action volunteers every Sunday evening. The volunteers prepare a two course meal for those in need in the local Loughborough areas. LSU Action are asking for donations towards the food for this project, each week it costs ~£40 to feed our service users. Thank you for your generosity!
Title: LSU Action Soup Kitchen

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

There are over 100,000 homeless children in Britain. They’ll spend winter in places like B&Bs or hostels. Because being homeless isn’t just about sleeping rough.

Homelessness figures out on 23 March 2016  show that 14,470 households were accepted as homeless between October and December last year – a rise of 6% across England and 10% in London compared to the previous year.

We hope our event will raise awareness, please help us support them.

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. 

Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.

Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description: @MKTG we like to help our neighbours. They are a part of our community. We often see the queues outside the soup kitchen as it is on our block, we often see those queues while we are going out to buy our lunch: in may ways a privileged position - we have jobs and we can afford a sandwich at lunch , and we have a roof over our heads. We thought it would be good to get a different perspective on life so we all decided to help by volunteering at the kitchen - and we now all work there month in and month out. We also help to raise funds whenever it is needed. We had a film quiz and raised the cash to replace their broken down refrigerator for instance. This page is our on going commitment to help our neighbours.

As part of the UCKG HelpCentre's response to Covid-19,we’d like to tell you about an exciting new initiative called 5Alive! We have worked and are continuing to work hard to deliver fi ve major community projects this year, with the aim of keeping various members of our community alive throughout this difficult time.
We currently operate a 24-hour helpline, run weekly soup kitchens in five different locations that have fed over 2,000 people throughout the pandemic, as well as food banks in several of our centres across the country. The initiative also includes two other projects: “Night Angels”, which sees our volunteers take to the streets during the night to provide basic necessities and food packs to those still sleeping rough; and also the Give Warmth Appeal, which extends aid not only to the homeless and those sleeping rough, but to children in hospitals, the children of prison inmates, and others, through gift-giving and the provision of items that will help those struggling get through the cold winter months.

Title: Waterside Apartments & Simon on the Streets

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
The American Soup Kitchen (SK) on Tottenham Court Road has been providing food to the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate everyday for over 30 years. With the recent COVID-19 related lockdown it witnessed a collapse in its corporate funding. We would like to assist them in raising some money as a result. 

At a time when most other soup kitchens have had to close, the SK has been serving approximately 150 meals per day. They have implemented social distancing measures such as take away meals and ensuring 2 metre distancing between Guests. 

The SK has adopted the government’s guidelines for charities in the work that it does to protect its staff, volunteers and beneficiaries.

For instance the SK has taken steps to protect its staff, volunteers and guests by enforcing social distancing using ground markers and security personnel and by insisting upon the use of sanitizers provided and by asking guests to move on once they’ve collected their hot and cold food parcels.  

We are writing to ask for your help by way of £15 per month for the next three months - so £45 to help see the SK through the worst of this global crisis. Our aim is to get 100 funders on board in this way which will help cover monthly running costs for about 50 Guests until corporate funders return post the lockdown. Over the last ten years we know many of you have supported the fantastic work of the SK, sometimes as volunteers and at other times through donations of food and clothing.  

A massive THANK YOU from us and from the SK ! 

 Paliwal  & Maru Families
Title: Soup Kitchen London Emergency Appeal

Description:
So my beard has been with me since time began and many of you have said in the past "im gonna cut it off in your sleep".  Well here's your chance to help my beard earn some money for a worthy cause.

I have been volunteering at Soup Kitchen in Newbury for the last few years and i cant think of a better cause to enable them to support the most vunerable in society.  Not just the homeless, anyone who comes through the door.

So in the words of Bob Geldoff “Give us your f***ing money” ;-)ill

I'll be cutting it off on my shift at the Soup Kitchen on Nov 21st.

From 12th November 2018, the Newbury Soup Kitchen is division of the HAVEN (West Berkshire) homeless charity. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the Newbury homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate than others. The primary operation is a friendly drop-in centre for vulnerable adults who perhaps have mental health issues or are just lonely. All are greeted with hot food and drinks every Thursday evening. A warm welcome awaits people who wish to socialise, find support and enjoy a hot meal.

Description:
This is our story..

We are a group of young people taking part in NCS's Summer Scheme. Part of our social action, is to pick a charity and raise awareness, funding and get our hands dirty by giving back to our community.

We have chosen Southport Soup Kitchen as we find their work so important within our local community.

We are hoping to raise money, raise awareness and collecting the essentials like shampoo/sanitary products/soap/food/water/gloves/socks and other things that will make life a little easier for the homeless and people struggling, in and around Southport. 

Any donations are encouraged, we are grateful for every single penny and we hope that you will encourage your family and friends to help us reach our fundraising goal. 

(If you'd like to give us tinned good and long lasting foods, you can drop them off at Southport Community Church Southbank Road, and label the bag with 'Catch 22, Southport group 4' and it will be added to our collection. 

Thank you for your time.

Title: Silver Spoon supporting Peterborough Soup Kitchen

Description:
This Boxing Day, Chris, Barny and Cathy will be hitting the streets of Central London with a makeshift soup kitchen in the back of 'The Bongo', to give out hot soup, Christmas snacks, doggy treats and blankets to the homeless.

On Boxing Day we'll be mobile around central London in the morning and then pitching up near Trafalgar Square, if you wish to support us on the day please come along with your warm heart and whatever wish you wish to donate.

We've had lots of generous donations from friends already, including soup, blankets, dog food, sleeping bags and serving equipment. Thanks so much to everyone who's helped us so far!

For those of our friends who are simply too far away and would like to help please donate what you can to Crisis.

And for those only able to support in spirit, we would be grateful if you can share our plight with your friends to help raise awareness of the homeless crisis this Christmas.

Thanks so much,

Chris, Barny & Cathy

X
Title: Boxing Day Bongo - A Mobile Soup Kitchen #xmaspresent

Description:
The last few months have seen immense suffering and hardship from storms and flooding. However the outbreak of the Coronavirus has quite literally changed everyones lives and turned society upside down.
However, The Salvation Army is resolute and strong and just as we did in the Spanish Flu pandemic, and during the bombing and the Blitz we will carry on, doing what we can to support people and communities  in the ways that we can, within the Government guidelines.
In true Salvation Army Spirit, our greatest strength is our flexible, responsive local presence. Right now, each of our 650 corps and community centres will know exactly what the most effective things are to do. We are not just responding to the virus impact in one or two ways, but dozens and dozens of different ways, from food banks to counselling, from supporting NHS isolation units to checking up on people who are living alone
Please give what you can to enable us to help as many people as possible!
Title: Parkhead Corps's East Glasgow Soup Kitchen & Food Banks

CharityName: St John the Evangelist, Brownswood Park
Description:
Throughout the pandemic Ows and I have been collecting from our neighbours for our local foodbank. We have now been collecting weekly since May and the need keeps growing; with a 50% increase in people using the food bank, this is only set to increase as more people lose their jobs. 

This is why I have decided to make a pretty cold and miserable month a tad more gruelling by running 5k a day throughout November, to raise money for the St John's Soup Kitchen and Foodbank. I will be putting my knees on the line so please donate to this great cause. Also, if you're  in the area please feel free to join me on a run, there will be 30 to choose from. 

Help St John's to keep running our soup kitchen and food bank. They have given out 2000 meals since the beginning of April, and are now giving out 100 food parcels a week. They are a non-referral service, and will help anyone who comes to their doors.
Title: 5K a day for St John's Soup Kitchen and Food Bank

Description:
﻿This summer we are going to a shanty-town called Las Laderas in Peru with our parents where we will stay in a children's refuge and help to build a new soup kitchen.

Our Dad is a Founding Trustee of the Amoria Bond Charitable Trust which has developed a long-term partnership over the last 10 years with Project Peru and the community of Las Laderas, and has funded and assisted with numerous initiatives including building houses, providing much needed donations of food, IT and sports equipment, and funding the utilities for a local soup kitchen.

Sadly, Las Laderas remains in deep poverty and is growing into increasingly tough and inhospitable terrain up the barren mountain-side. The community's existing single soup-kitchen can not cope with the growing levels of hunger and demand. So the Amoria Bond Charitable Trust has committed to funding the building of an additional new soup-kitchen in 2019 which will provide 100s of meals a week, bring local employment for builders and community workers, and ensure food-security for children and other vulnerable members of the community.

We hope you will donate to help raise the £10,000 it will cost to build the soup kitchen.

THANK YOU!!!

Dylan and Ollie Daw
Title: Help build a soup kitchen in Peru to feed 100s of vulnerable people!

Description:
Action for Pulmonary Fibrosis (APF) is a growing community of patients, families, researchers and healthcare professionals striving to find a cure for pulmonary fibrosis so that everyone affected by the disease has a better future. We provide personalised support to patient and families - and raise awareness of pulmonary fibrosis through campaigning, fundraising and education. We are also committed to funding research to improve the quality of life for people living with pulmonary fibrosis today and tomorrow.

Pook's story is available on my website : www.thetruthaboutipf.  

He fought a brave and far too short battle against this disease.
Title: Pook Zanetti's Birthday

Title: DAVID's Merry dancemas

Description:
Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks.As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Soup kitchens need even more support right now as we go into winter during this challenging time. Everyone deserves food security and Id like to do my little bit. Classes are open to all, I will be running them on different days and times so as many people as possible can access them.

Mindfulness is a skill which has helped me a lot in my life and I cant wait to pass this skill onto more people. Taking care of mental health has never been so important.

Title: Eva & Eliza's Birthday Fundraiser

Description:
We are a local, growing driving school, and we're hosting a Mock Test Day. This is where full licence holders can visit us, and one of our friendly instructors will take the full licence holder out for a 30 minute mock driving test, assess their driving, and provide feedback and results at the end. 

We're really interested to see how many full licence holders still have the skills to pass their driving test - whether they've been driving for 1 year, or 15 years. 

We'd love for this to be a fun, informal event, where people can put their driving skills to the test, whilst raising money for such a deserving, hard working, local charity. 

We hope to see you there!

Title: RWcrafts support our community

Description:
Thank you to everyone on our team for choosing to give up doing Secret Santa in order to help others less fortunate and support the work of a local charity.

This charity helps deal with homelessness by providing food to those in need. Homelessness is something that is very close to my heart.

When I was 21, not many people know this but I nearly found myself out on the streets. Had it not been for the help of a friend then I would have had nowhere to go and may not be where I am today. No one should ever have to face this situation in modern society. 

We have now opened this up to anyone who also wants to donate towards this amazing charity, every little helps!
Title: Our Not-So-Secret Santa

Description:

My new challenge involves visiting all 100 counties of the U.K. raising money for 100 local charities along the way.

Three charities from the County of Cambridgeshire were offered to my viewers and they voted to raise money for the Peterborough Soup Kitchen whilst we are in the Cambridgeshire area. 

You can read the full story at:

https://thetraveltroll.uk


You can follow my journey on Youtube at:
https://www.youtube.com/c/TheTravelTroll

Thank You.

The Soup Kitchen is the only place in Southport that provides a premises where people of the homeless community and those in need can go and sit down to have a hot meal, drink and a friendly chat. 

I have volunteered there for just under three months, in which I have learnt so much and has made me see things differently. Every single volunteer is so dedicated and it is such a privilege to volunteer along side them.

I am doing the Skydive to raise money, and give something back as I know it will go a very long way.

Thank you so much for your donations and support.
Title: Jonathan's page

Description:
I am studying Art and Design at College and I have chosen to focus on Urban Environment for my Final Major Project, specifically Homelessness in Peterborough. This is just a small part of my project and I'm partially hoping that it will work as a form of non-traditional public art. Whilst brainstorming ideas for this project, I focused on Peterborough because I have lived here most of my life meaning I have a personal attachment to this specific Urban Environment. A big issue in most urban environments is homelessness because of the overpopulation of the area, meaning it is difficult to earn money and afford a roof over your head, let alone food to eat. This is a huge problem in Peterborough so I'm using this project to start a campaign and raise awareness.

I have started this fundraising page mainly to raise awareness about Peterborough Soup Kitchen. Upon researching them recently, I have found out that they provide food and drinks for 35 - 76 people A DAY. The charity deserves the donations and if you live in or have visited Peterborough, you will know just how many unfortunate, homeless people there are on the streets. I am only asking for small donations as I can sympathise about not having a lot of spare money.

Title: Yaz's FMP: Urban Environment: Homelessness

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

An estimated 320,000 people are homeless in the UK, according to the latest research by Shelter. This equates to one in every 201 Brits and was an increase of four per cent on the previous year’s number.

Rough sleepers are just the visible tip of the iceberg when it comes to registering and understanding the homelessness crisis. The widening net of poverty and the breakdown of mental health provision means numbers are growing. Between 4,000 and 5,000 people bed down on the streets on any given night, a figure that has almost doubled since 2010.

Southport Soup Kitchen’s primary goal is simple:  to provide hot, nourishing food and beverages free of charge to the homeless and disadvantaged of Southport and the immediate locality.

Description: Jan 2017 Meryl set up Newbury Soup Kitchen. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the local homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate. During the Covid-19 crisis, they provide about 300 meals a week. This is done by way of delivery. The food is cooked, bagged up in individual ‘grab bags’ which have a hot vegetarian meal, fruit, snack, drink and homemade cake or biscuit. Newbury Soup Kitchen works solely on food supermarket/public donations, public monetary donations and grants. They cannot do what we do without this. Alexandra and Gabriella feel strongly that they want to help the homeless and those struggling for food at this time.

Description:
Hey Guys! 

So you know this ongoing crisis of homeless starving people and people living below the poverty line, it really brings me down seeing how the numbers have risen, especially here in Peterborough. 

After thinking about the silly ways I spend money, like buying £16 boxes of teabags and how crazy that seems when so many people would rely on that to feed themselves,

I thought I'd actually do something about it and I shall be living on £1 a day for two weeks and all the donations will be going to our local soup kitchen here in Peterborough. 

So tonight when you're eating dinner, or opening some wine or just reaching for a quick snack thinks about hose who can't.

Title: Efue's Festive Fundraise For The Community

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The evenings are still dark, and the weather is still cold, what better time to indulge in some home cooked comfort food.  As you maybe aware, I love to cook, bake, and generally make food, so what a perfect opportunity to take advantage and raise funds for CLIC Sargent.  I shall take to the kitchen to help the 11 children and young people in the UK who will hear the devastating news they have cancer today.  At the moment CLIC can only support two out of three young people who need their assistance. CLIC want to give all young cancer patients and their families the support they need, for as long as they need it.  This can be done with your help.

Here's how your support can help

  • £4 could pay for a CLIC Sargent storybook that explains childhood cancer to children in simple, easy to understand language;
  • £15 could pay for a copy of CLIC Sargent’s DVD to help bereaved families understand and cope with their grief;
  • £46 could pay for a CLIC Sargent Social Worker to be there soon after diagnosis, giving a family one-to-one support;
  • £170 could pay for a CLIC Sargent grant
    to help stop cancer costs spiralling;
  • £330 could pay for a family to stay 10 nights at a CLIC Sargent Home from Home, providing free accommodation close to where their child is receiving cancer treatment;
  • £570 could pay for a CLIC Sargent Play
    Specialist for a week to help a child prepare
    and cope with treatment.

Whilst I ask for a minimum of £2.50, there is no specific donation amount, but from the above you can see what good even a donation of £4 can do.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. Title: Pall Harbourgate Appeal for the LifeHouse Kitchen

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit.

The team in Gleeds Southampton are going to run/walk/swim/row/SUP/cycle as far as we possibly can during the summer of 2020 to raise money for LifeHouse (http://www.lifehouse.org.uk/). 

The Life House is a not-for-profit charity which is a Soup Kitchen and support centre for the homeless and those in need living in Portsmouth and Southsea.

We provide food, hot meals, clothing, counselling and general advice to vulnerable men and women and target the issues of homelessness and addiction locally.

We aim to create an environment of compassion and care, where people feel they belong, are accepted; and where they can build a sense of self-worth and confidence – a place where we can be generous with our time, energy and practical resources; where we can go the extra mile.

The Life House is a converted building which we have outgrown over the years. This means we are limited to the amount of service users that can be seated at any  one seating for the hot meals we provide. We have to ask out service used to queue up outside in the wind and rain and limit the time they can sit and have a rest bite from the elements.

Our intention is to expand so we can accommodate more service users at any one time. The building works we are raising money for will incorporate expanding in to the neighbouring church so we can sit more service users for hot meals. We plans to increase the capacity of the existing kitchen and make it more operationally efficient to help free up volunteers for they can focus on helping the service users.  

We would also like to expand to offer more services such as online training, expand our counselling service, hair dressing, and other wellbeing services such as, podiatry and medical advice etc.

Title: Jason's page

Description:
We will be able soon, with your generous support, to seat and feed double the number of homeless, underhoused and rehabilitating guests 2-3 times a week in this new, large, comfortable space. For the first time they will all be able to choose where they sit and for how long (especially vital in cold and wet weather when rough sleepers need to take time to “warm-up” and dry out). The newly enlarged LifeHouse will seat 50-55 diners, not the 28 we squeeze in now!

Our guests will not be hurried along to make way for the next person. Sadly queueing outside in all weathers had been a regular feature of the LifeHouse up to now.  On a Thursday evening diners can enjoy some live music from all sorts of local artists free of charge. So this can become an unhurried, dignified and sociable meal out for our guests rather than a short, scrambled meal limited by time and have coffee after in the sofa area.

The major design, surveying, permissions and building work, is being done and very generously paid for by PMC Construction: www.pmcconstruction.co.uk.  Since 1982, PMC Construction has developed housing and commercial schemes that are built to last.

The front of the building seen here will be the new, main dining room and we hope that you might decide to help us refurbish and equip it! The lighting is very outdated and needs replacing. We will need a range of trolleys and serving equipment. The old diner area will be kept to provide a space where people can get support can sit, have coffee, play table football or table-tennis or just chill out and socialise - something they don’t get to do before. 

In this season ahead we need to fund decoration, folding tables,
lighting, heated food trays, trolleys, extra fridge and floor coverings.
Title: RAISING FUNDS FOR DINING HALL REFURBISHMENT & EQUIPMENT

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Planning lessons and marking are no longer on my to do list in the evenings, so I have been able to help a local hub to sew scrubs and have recently started making a few face masks during my spare time. I thought this is a great opportunity to raise money for a charity that runs by the people who are very close to my heart. The LifeHouse is a resource, support centre and kitchen that serves hot food in Albert Road, Southsea. They aim to target immediate needs and issues surrounding homelessness and addiction for those in need in Southsea. This place relies heavily on a team of dedicated volunteers (who are amazing!!) and local donations with food, clothing etc. Since their recent site expansion and refurbishment, they are hoping to be able to upgrade their kitchen equipment, furniture, and more importantly to be able to accommodate more people who are in needs. 

There is no set price of each face mask, but we ask for minimum donation of £7 for each which include postage. Each mask contains a small strip of wire so it can sit nicely on your nose. With a pocket on the reverse side where you can insert additional materials. Pattern choices are limited so message me for stock availability. Once you have made your donation, message me with your pattern choice and address and I aim to dispatch within 5 working days (I can only make these in the evenings!)
Title: Vivys homemade face masks

Description:
Three members of our Canteen team are braving an abseil down The Spinnaker Tower this June!

Emma, Lacey and Beth will face their fears by abseiling 100m down the side of the city's iconic landmark all in aid of charity.

Our chosen charity for the year is The LifeHouse Southsea. Based in the heart of Southsea, The LifeHouse is a support centre and kitchen that targets the immediate needs and issues surrounding homelessness and addiction in Portsmouth.

All support will be greatly appreciated, whether it's a donation or simply going down to cheer them on! We wish them all the best of luck! Go on girls!

Team Canteen X
Title: The Canteen's Spinnaker Tower Abseil

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Written on 29.01.2020

In April 2020, it will be two years since I started my running journey with a Couch to 5K course.  So what better way to mark that anniversary than with a full marathon in Brighton.  The whole 26.2 miles.  Eeek!

Outdoor running wasn't something that I thought I would enjoy or be any good at...(I really didn't like cross country at school!)...but I soon found a huge passion for it, that I never knew I had.  Especially trail running or road running with great views.  I'm very lucky that I live next to the sea and nearby forests to explore.  The support of a great running club has made a massive difference.  Social running is never dull.

I normally  do races just for fun...but running my first marathon provides the perfect opportunity to help a worth while local cause.  

I first heard about the Lifehouse charity when I took part in the Great South running weekend with colleagues back in October 2018.  We jointly raised funds and I knew it was a charity I would like to support again.  They do a fantastic job supporting the homeless and those with addictions in Southsea.  If you can help at all please, that would be marvellous! 

11-09-20 UPDATE

We all know Covid-19 tried to get in the way of us having fun. The Brighton marathon was of course cancelled.   I was gutted.  I am still determined to run a marathon though, as soon as I can!

The plan is to run the Portsmouth Coastal Marathon on 20th December.  I'm about to properly restart my long distance training.  I haven't let my fitness slip at all during lockdown ...so feeling ready to do this.

06-11-20 UPDATE

The Portsmouth Coastal marathon was cancelled in October, so a new plan was quickly hatched.  My husband and I signed up to the God of Thunder II race at Denbies wine estates in Dorking.  This was a 5K lapped event that took place on 1st November.  We managed 8 laps for the full marathon distance!  This wasn't a flat marathon.  There was 2,600 feet of elevation thrown in for fun!

The medal was rather epic.  See photo above.

I am so pleased we both managed to run our first marathons in 2020 after all!

Thank you for reading

Title: Alan's birthday fundraiser

Description:
Everyone deserves to feel a sense of belonging; I believe this notion can be found everywhere and anywhere, yet when environments are openly hostile to ones presence, its hard to cultivate this sense of place. This is why the Refugee Community Kitchen is such a valuable initiative, for they are nourishing, nurturing and so unifying displaced people in Northern France, through cooking and distributing hot, culturally sensitive meals in a safe space. 

Active since 2015, the RCK have continued to operate despite the turbulence of camp destruction, police brutality and settlement evictions. The unpredictable Covid-19 restrictions and looming winter months are placing further strains on their mission and to add to the crisis, in early October the French authorities imposed limitations on food distribution within Calais. Clearly, the RCK needs the love and support right now so they may continue providing safe, judgement free spaces where people can gather and tap into a sense of belonging, so vital in these disturbing circumstances. 

In December I will be venturing to Calais to help the RCK continue their phenomenal work. I believe an opportunity to aid hundreds of people, right on our doorstep, who are going without the essentials to human well-being is a privilege not to be passed up. Equally, the profound effect a nourishing meal can have on the body, mind and spirit is truly miraculous, therefore I invite you to open your heart and support my mission, in doing so, the RCK and all the people they serve. 

Contributing could look like diverting your coffee money (or perhaps your lunch money!) towards this fundraiser; sharing this page to family, friends, (or foes...). Equally, if you’d like to donate kitchen supplies and materials instead of funds, please follow the link bellow to see their ‘Food/Kitchen Needs List’ and reach out. I will organise the collection, storage and transportation of these life-changing supplies ready for December. 

Any act of kindness would be gratefully received; it means the world that you are on this page right now, ready to make a difference.

Love and Light

Ari <3 


Food/Kitchen Needs List: 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Byxq9mQj3bPvq5WRxRZHfApBqTGGMVmjxq34Maspqa4/edit
